questions.text: Which cerebellar zone is mainly associated with processing proprioceptive information?
Which pathway involves inhibitory projections originating from the cerebellar nuclei, contributing to the regulation of motor activity and coordination?
questions.explanation:
Cerebellar Output

Excitatory

Cerebellar nuclei to Brainstem nuclei (via Glutamate)

Inhibitory

Purkinjee cells to Cerebellum (via GABA)

Cerebellar Nuclei to Inferior Olive: Nucleo-Olivary Pathway (via GABA)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cerebellar circuitry is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Climbing fibres directly excite Purkinje cells by forming extensive synaptic connections.

options.label: B
options.text: Mossy fibres excite Purkinje cells through granule cells, creating a diffuse excitatory effect.

options.label: C
options.text: Purkinje cells send excitatory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei.

options.label: D
options.text: Stellate, basket, and Golgi cells serve as inhibitory interneurons in the cerebellar cortex.

questions.correct_answer: C. Purkinje cells send excitatory signals to deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe vertigo, bilateral hearing loss, and tinnitus. He also exhibits facial weakness on the right side and demonstrates ataxia when attempting to walk. An MRI performed to evaluate the condition is given below. Which artery is most likely affected in this patient’s condition?
Which type of fibres enter the cerebellum via the middle cerebellar peduncle?
questions.explanation:
Afferent fibres

Tract

Enter Cerebellum Via

Target and Function

Climbing fibres

Olivo-cerebellar

(Option A ruled out)

Inferior cerebellar peduncle (decussates)

Excitatory terminals on Purkinje cells (glutamate)

Mossy fibres

Cerebro-ponto- cerebellar (Option B)

Middle cerebellar peduncle (decussates)

Excitatory terminals on granule cells (glutamate), which are excitatory to Purkinje cells

Spinocerebellar (Option C ruled out)
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle
  • Superior cerebellar peduncle

Vestibulo-cerebellar (Option D ruled out)

Inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: Which of the following structures receives direct projections from the dentate nucleus?

options.label: C
options.text: The anterior nucleus of the thalamus

questions.correct_answer: B. Ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus

questions.text: The fastigial nucleus primarily projects to which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Connections of Cerebellum

Part of cerebellum

Cerebellar Nuclei

Centre

Neocerebellum

Dentate

Red Nucleus and Thalamus

(Option B ruled out)

Paleocerebellum

Globose and Emobliform

Red Nucleus (Option A ruled out)

Archicerebellum

Fastigial

Vestibular Nuclei

(Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following intrinsic neurons are correctly matched with their respective layers in the cerebellar cortex?
questions.explanation:
Layers of the cerebellar cortex

Molecular (plexiform) layer

(Option C ruled out)

Purkinje cell layer

(Option B ruled out)

Granular layer

(Option A ruled out)

It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells.

It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells.

The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells, along with a few larger Golgi cells.

These nerve cells are of two types:

(a) Basket cells

(b) Stellate cells.

The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei.

Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory.

questions.text: Which of the following deep cerebellar nuclei is primarily involved in the smooth execution of skilled voluntary movements?
questions.explanation:
Deep Cerebellar nuclei

Dentate Nucleus

(Option D)

Emboliform Nucleus

Globose Nucleus

Fastigial Nucleus
  • Largest and most lateral.
  • Receives input from the neocerebellum.
  • Involved in coordinating skilled, voluntary movements, especially of the limbs.
  • Efferent fibres exit through the superior cerebellar peduncle.
  • Oval-shaped, medial to the dentate nucleus.
  • The emboliform nucleus combined with the globose nucleus is called Nucleus Interposus.
  • Receives input from the paleocerebellum.
  • Plays a role in general motor coordination.

(Option B ruled out)
  • Rounded, positioned between the emboliform and fastigial nuclei.
  • Also part of the paleocerebellum.
  • Works together with the emboliform nucleus for motor control.

(Option C ruled out)
  • Most medial, near the midline.
  • Receives input from the archicerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe.
  • Important for balance, posture, and coordinating head and eye movements.

(Option A ruled out)

questions.text: What is the significance of the second decussation of the ventral spinocerebellar tract within the cerebellum?

options.label: D
options.text: Causes all fibres to terminate bilaterally

questions.text: From which anatomical structure does the dorsal spinocerebellar tract originate?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: Which cerebellar peduncle is primarily composed of only afferent fibres?
questions.explanation:
Cerebellar Peduncles
 

Afferent

Efferent

Superior cerebellar peduncle

Ventral Spinocerebellar Tract

All efferent fibres from dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose nuclei

(Option C ruled out)

Middle cerebellar peduncle

Pontocerebellar Mossy Fibre Pathway

No efferent fibres

(Option A)

Inferior cerebellar peduncle

  • Dorsal Spinocerebellar Tract
  • Olivocerebellar Tract
  • Reticulocerebellar Tract

Few efferents from the cerebellum to the medulla oblongata, mainly to vestibular nuclei and reticular formation.

(Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which cerebellar lobe is associated with maintaining balance and controlling eye movements?
Identify the correct option.

Match the following neural columns with their corresponding cranial nerve nuclei. 1. General Somatic Efferent (GSE) A) Nucleus ambiguus 2. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) B) Edinger-Westphal nucleus 3. General Visceral Efferent (GVE) C) Oculomotor nucleus 4. Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) D) Nucleus of the solitary tract
questions.explanation:
1. General Somatic Efferent (GSE)

 

The GSE column controls muscles derived from somites, specifically the striated muscles.

C) Oculomotor nucleus

 

In the brainstem, it is represented by nuclei like the oculomotor nucleus, which innervates the extraocular muscles, facilitating eye movement.

2. Special Visceral Afferent (SVA)

 

The SVA column is responsible for processing special sensory information related to taste.

D) Nucleus of the solitary tract

 

In the brainstem, the nucleus of the solitary tract receives taste signals from the tongue, transmitted by cranial nerves like the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves.

3. General Visceral Efferent (GVE)

 

The GVE column regulates autonomic functions, particularly parasympathetic innervation.

B) Edinger-Westphal nucleus

 

The Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain is part of this system, controlling pupil constriction and lens accommodation.

4. Special Visceral Efferent (SVE)

 

The SVE column innervates muscles derived from the branchial arches, responsible for functions like swallowing and speech.

A) Nucleus ambiguus

 

The nucleus ambiguus provides motor innervation to muscles involved in these actions, via cranial nerves like the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly arranges the brainstem nuclei from medial to lateral in the brainstem?

options.label: A
options.text: Oculomotor nucleus → Trochlear nucleus → Edinger Westphal nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: Hypoglossal nucleus → Dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus → Nucleus tractus solitarius

options.label: C
options.text: Motor nuclei of Trigeminal → Motor nuclei of Facial → Abducent nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: Nucleus ambiguus → Hypoglossal nucleus → Nucleus tractus solitarius

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypoglossal nucleus → Dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus → Nucleus tractus solitarius

questions.text: Which nuclei belong to the Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) column?

options.label: B
options.text: Sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve

questions.explanation:

GSE

(General Somatic Efferent)

(Option C ruled out)

SVE

(Option D ruled out)

(General Somatic Afferent)

(Option B ruled out)

SSA

(Special Somatic Afferent)

(Option A)
  • Oculomotor nucleus (III)
  • Trochlear nucleus (IV)
  • Abducent nucleus (VI)
  • Hypoglossal nucleus (XII)
  • Motor nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve (V)
  • Motor nucleus of the facial nerve (VII)
  • Nucleus ambiguus (IX, X, XI)

 
  • Edinger Westphal nucleus (III)
  • Superior salivatory nucleus (VII) 
  • Inferior salivatory nucleus (IX)
  • Dorsal nucleus of Vagus (X)
  • Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

(GVA - IX, X)

(SVA - VII, IX)
  • Sensory nuclei of Trigeminal Nerve (V, IX, X)

 
  • Vestibular nuclei (VIII)
  • Cochlear nuclei (VIII)
  • The lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus (II).
  • Olfactory bulb (I)

questions.text: Which artery is most commonly occluded, leading to medial medullary syndrome and lateral pontine syndrome, respectively?
Which arteries supply the posterior region of the superior medulla and pons respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior Spinal Artery and Posterior Spinal Artery

options.label: D
options.text: Superior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery and Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

questions.text: Which artery supplies the posterior region of the midbrain?
The baroreceptor reflex that helps regulate blood pressure involves general visceral afferent (GVA) fibres from which of the following receptors and pathways?

options.label: A
options.text: Carotid body via the glossopharyngeal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Aortic bodies via the vagus nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Carotid sinus via the vagus nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary arteries via the glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Aortic bodies via the vagus nerve

questions.text: The nucleus of the solitary tract receives ______ sensations from the carotid body and carotid sinus primarily through _____ nerve.
questions.correct_answer: C. General Visceral Afferent; Glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the jaw jerk reflex is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a spinal reflex initiated by tapping the jaw.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves the mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus as an integration centre.

options.label: C
options.text: The efferent pathway includes the mandibular nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a monosynaptic reflex involving a single synapse.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a spinal reflex initiated by tapping the jaw.

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei of the trigeminal nerve is primarily responsible for proprioceptive sensations from the muscles of mastication?
questions.explanation:
Sensory component of Trigeminal Nuclei

The motor component of Trigeminal Nuclei
  • Carries pain, temperature, touch, pressure, and proprioception from the face.
  • Main sensory nucleus - touch and pressure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Spinal nucleus - pain and temperature. It extends till C2 of the spinal cord.
  • Mesencephalic nucleus - proprioception.
  • The motor nucleus receives inputs from both cerebral hemispheres, the reticular formation, and the red nucleus and forms a reflex arc with the mesencephalic nucleus.
  • Supplies muscles of mastication-
    • Temporalis
    • Masseter
    • Lateral pterygoid
    • Medial pterygoid
  • Other muscles like
    • Tensor tympani
    • Tensor veli palatini
    • Mylohyoid
    • Anterior belly of digastric

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding damage to the midline brainstem nuclei is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Damage to the oculomotor nucleus can result in the eye looking laterally and ptosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Injury to the trochlear nucleus leads to difficulty in upward gaze and may cause a compensatory head tilt to the same side.

options.label: C
options.text: Damage to the abducens nucleus results in medial strabismus, causing the affected eye to turn inward.

options.label: D
options.text: Lesion of the hypoglossal nucleus leads to weakness and atrophy of the tongue on the affected side.

questions.correct_answer: B. Injury to the trochlear nucleus leads to difficulty in upward gaze and may cause a compensatory head tilt to the same side.

questions.text: A 65 y/o patient presents with sudden dizziness, difficulty swallowing, ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the trunk, ipsilateral ataxia, and giddiness. Which anatomical structure is responsible for the ipsilateral loss of temperature sensation on the face of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. Spinal nucleus and tract of the trigeminal nerve
